stereotypes.name: AchievedEffect
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that exists between an ActualState  (e.g., observed/measured during testing) of an element that attempts to achieve a DesiredEffect and an Achiever.

stereotypes.name: Achiever
stereotypes.notes: An ActualResource, ActualProject or ActualEnterprisePhase that can deliver a DesiredEffect.

stereotypes.name: ActivityPerformableUnderCondition
stereotypes.notes: The ActualCondition under which an Activity is performed.

stereotypes.name: ActivitySupportsService
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that a process is necessary for the implementation of a service.

stereotypes.name: ActsUpon
stereotypes.notes: Asserts that something (subject) is acted upon by an OperationalActivity (activity).

stereotypes.name: ActualCondition
stereotypes.notes: An individual describing an actual situation with respect to circumstances under which an OperationalActivity, Function or ServiceFunction can be performed.

stereotypes.name: ActualConditionToActualResource
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that a actual resource is an actual situation.

stereotypes.name: ActualEnduringTask
stereotypes.notes: An actual undertaking recognized by an enterprise as being essential to achieving its goals - i.e. a strategic specification of what the enterprise does.

stereotypes.name: ActualEnterprisePhase
stereotypes.notes: The ActualState that describes the phase of an Enterprise endeavor.

stereotypes.name: ActualEnvironment
stereotypes.notes: The ActualState that describes the circumstances of an Environment.

stereotypes.name: ActualLocation
stereotypes.notes: The ActualState that describes a physical location, for example using text to provide an address, Geo-coordinates, etc.

stereotypes.name: ActualMeasurement
stereotypes.notes: An actual value that is applied to a Measurement.

stereotypes.name: ActualMeasurementSet
stereotypes.notes: A set of ActualMeasurements.

stereotypes.name: ActualMeasurementSetAppliesFor
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which actual measurement applies for an element.

stereotypes.name: ActualOrganization
stereotypes.notes: An actual formal or informal organizational unit, e.g. "Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency", "UAF team Alpha".

stereotypes.name: ActualOrganizationalResource
stereotypes.notes: Abstract element for an ActualOrganization, ActualPerson or ActualPost.

stereotypes.name: ActualOrganizationRole
stereotypes.notes: An ActualOrganizationalResource that is applied to a ResourceRole.

stereotypes.name: ActualPerson
stereotypes.notes: An individual human being.

stereotypes.name: ActualPost
stereotypes.notes: An actual, specific post, an instance of a Post "type" - e.g., "President of the United States of America." where the Post would be president.

stereotypes.name: ActualProject
stereotypes.notes: A time-limited endeavor to provide a specific set of ActualResource that meet specific Capability needs.

stereotypes.name: ActualProjectConsults
stereotypes.notes: A relation that expresses that a project consults an OrganizationalResource.

stereotypes.name: ActualProjectDependency
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that is a dependency of a actualproject on a actualproject.

stereotypes.name: ActualProjectInforms
stereotypes.notes: A relation that expresses that a project informs an OrganizationalResource.

stereotypes.name: ActualProjectMilestone
stereotypes.notes: An event with a start date in a ActualProject from which progress is measured.

stereotypes.name: ActualProjectMilestoneRole
stereotypes.notes: An ActualProjectMilestone that is applied to a ProjectMilestoneRole.

stereotypes.name: ActualPropertySet
stereotypes.notes: A set or collection of Actual properties.

stereotypes.name: ActualResource
stereotypes.notes: Role in an Organisation, where the role carries the authority to undertake a function - through the ActualOrganizationalResource given the role has the responsibility.

stereotypes.name: ActualResourceNeededByActualProjectMilestone
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual resource is needed by actual project milestones.

stereotypes.name: ActualResourceRelationship
stereotypes.notes: An actual resource flow existing between ActualResources (i.e. flow of data, people, materiel, or energy).

stereotypes.name: ActualResourceRole
stereotypes.notes: An instance of a ResourcePerformer.

stereotypes.name: ActualResourceToActualProjectMilestone
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual resource is mapped to actual project milestones.

stereotypes.name: ActualResponsibleResource
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping responsible OrganizationalResources.

stereotypes.name: ActualService
stereotypes.notes: An individual ServiceSpecification.

stereotypes.name: ActualServiceSpecificationRole
stereotypes.notes: An instance of a ServiceSpecification in context of a ServiceSpecification.

stereotypes.name: ActualState
stereotypes.notes: Abstract element that applies temporal extent to a set of elements realized as Instance Specifications.

stereotypes.name: AffectedActivity
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which resource is affected by a operational activity.

stereotypes.name: AffectedFunctions
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which function is affected by a resource.

stereotypes.name: AffectedResource
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which operational activity is affected by a resource.

stereotypes.name: Alias
stereotypes.notes: A metamodel Artifact used to define an alternative name for an element.

stereotypes.name: AlignsWithGoal
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an element is aligned with a goal.

stereotypes.name: ArbitraryConnector
stereotypes.notes: Represents a visual indication of a connection used in high level operational concept diagrams.

stereotypes.name: ArchitecturalDescription
stereotypes.notes: An Architecture Description is a work product used to express the Architecture of some System Of Interest. It provides executive-level summary information about the architecture description in a consistent form to allow quick reference and comparison between architecture descriptions -- It includes assumptions, constraints, and limitations that may affect high-level decisions relating to an architecture-based work program.

stereotypes.name: ArchitecturalReference
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that specifies that one architectural description refers to another.

stereotypes.name: ArchitecturalSequence
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that specifies that one architectural description is the successor of another.

stereotypes.name: Architecture
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents a generic architecture. Subtypes are OperationalArchitecture and ResourceArchitecture.

stereotypes.name: ArchitectureForProject
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that a architectural description belongs to a actual project.

stereotypes.name: ArchitectureMetadata
stereotypes.notes: Information associated with an ArchitecturalDescription, that supplements the standard set of tags used to summarize the Architecture. It states things like what methodology was used, notation, etc.

stereotypes.name: Asset
stereotypes.notes: Asset as applied to Security views, an abstract type that indicates the types of elements that can be considered as a subject for security analysis.

stereotypes.name: AssetRole
stereotypes.notes: AssetRole as applied to Security views, an abstract element that indicates the type of elements  that can be considered as a subject for security analysis in the particular context (currently no security viewpoints in the framework).

stereotypes.name: BoundaryCondition
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which environment is relevant to an resource exchange.

stereotypes.name: BusinessProcess
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents a behavior or process (i.e. a Function or OperationalActivity) that can be performed by a Performer.

stereotypes.name: BWRequirement
stereotypes.notes: Abstract base class for requirements.

stereotypes.name: Capability
stereotypes.notes: A high level specification of the enterprise's ability to execute a specified course of action.

stereotypes.name: CapabilityConfiguration
stereotypes.notes: A composite structure representing the physical and human resources (and their interactions) in an enterprise, assembled to meet a capability).

stereotypes.name: CapabilityDependency
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that asserts that one Capability is dependent from another.

stereotypes.name: CapabilityForTask
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that asserts that a Capability is required in order for an Enterprise to conduct a phase of an EnduringTask.

stereotypes.name: CapabilityGeneralization
stereotypes.notes: A CapabilityGeneralization is a taxonomic relationship between a more general Capability and a more specific Capability.

stereotypes.name: CapabilityRole
stereotypes.notes: A high level specification of the enterprise's ability to execute a specified course of action.

stereotypes.name: CapabilityRoleDependency
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that asserts that one CapabilityRole is dependent from another.

stereotypes.name: CapableElement
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents a structural element that can perform behaviors (i.e. OperationalActivity).

stereotypes.name: Checks
stereotypes.notes: Relation that shows that an acceptance criterion (FitCriterion) is valid for a functional or non-functional requirement.

stereotypes.name: Classification
stereotypes.notes: Classification according to STANAG 1059.

stereotypes.name: Classified
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that indicates which classification an element has.

stereotypes.name: Command
stereotypes.notes: A type of ResourceExchange that asserts that one OrganizationalResource commands another.

stereotypes.name: Competence
stereotypes.notes: A specific set of abilities defined by knowledge, skills and aptitude.

stereotypes.name: CompetenceForRole
stereotypes.notes: A tuple used to associate an organizational role with a specific set of required competencies.

stereotypes.name: CompliesViewpoint
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that expresses that a view has been created according to the specifications of a viewpoint.

stereotypes.name: ConceptItem
stereotypes.notes: Abstract, an item which may feature in a HighLevelOperationalConcept.

stereotypes.name: ConceptRole
stereotypes.notes: Usage of a ConceptItem in the context of a HighLevelOperationalConcept.

stereotypes.name: Concern
stereotypes.notes: Interest in an EnterprisePhase (EnterprisePhase is synonym for System in ISO 42010) relevant to one or more of its stakeholders.

stereotypes.name: ConcernForActualEnterprisePhase
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which concerns are covered by an actual enterprise phase.

stereotypes.name: ConcernForView
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which concerns are covered by view.

stereotypes.name: ConcernForViewpoint
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which concerns are covered by viewpoint.

stereotypes.name: Condition
stereotypes.notes: A type that defines the Location, Environment and/or GeoPoliticalExtent.

stereotypes.name: ConflictsWith
stereotypes.notes: Relation that represents a conflict between two requirements.

stereotypes.name: ConformsTo
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an UAFElement conforms to a standard.

stereotypes.name: ConsumedBy
stereotypes.notes: Asserts that a service is consumed by a node. It is not required to know what provides the service.

stereotypes.name: Consumes
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that asserts that a service in someway contributes or assists in the execution of an OperationalActivity.

stereotypes.name: Control
stereotypes.notes: A type of ResourceExchange that asserts that one PhysicalResource controls another PhysicalResource (i.e.  the driver of a vehicle controlling the vehicle speed or direction).

stereotypes.name: DataElement
stereotypes.notes: A formalized representation of data that is managed by or exchanged between resources.

stereotypes.name: DataElementStoredIn
stereotypes.notes: Relation says that a data is stored in software.

stereotypes.name: DataModel
stereotypes.notes: A structural specification of data types, showing relationships between them that is devoid of implementation detail. The type of data captured in the DataModel is described using the enumaration DataModelKind (Conceptual,Logical and Physical).

stereotypes.name: DataRole
stereotypes.notes: A usage of DataElement that exists in the context of an ResourceAsset. It also allows the representation of the whole-part aggregation of DataElements.

stereotypes.name: Definition
stereotypes.notes: A comment containing a description of an element in the architecture.

stereotypes.name: DerivedFrom
stereotypes.notes: Relation that shows that a functional or non-functional requirement is based on a process, role and task carrier, information element or other element.

stereotypes.name: DescribedBy
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description describes an architecture.

stereotypes.name: DesiredEffect
stereotypes.notes: A tuple relating the Desirer (a Capability or OrganizationalResource) to an ActualState.

stereotypes.name: Desirer
stereotypes.notes: Abstract type used to group architecture elements that might desire a particular effect.

stereotypes.name: DocumentReference
stereotypes.notes: The element describes a regulation, instruction or a general document.

stereotypes.name: EnduringTask
stereotypes.notes: A type of template behavior recognized by an enterprise as being essential to achieving its goals - i.e. a template for a strategic specification of what the enterprise does.

stereotypes.name: Energy
stereotypes.notes: A representation of any kind of energy.

stereotypes.name: EnterpriseGoal
stereotypes.notes: A statement about a state or condition of the enterprise to be brought about or sustained through appropriate Means. An EnterpriseGoal amplifies an EnterpriseVision that is, it indicates what must be satisfied on a continuing basis to effectively attain the EnterpriseVision.

stereotypes.name: EnterprisePhase
stereotypes.notes: A current or future state of the wholeLifeEnterprise or another EnterprisePhase.

stereotypes.name: EnterpriseVision
stereotypes.notes: A Vision describes the future state of the enterprise, without regard to how it is to be achieved.

stereotypes.name: Environment
stereotypes.notes: A definition of the environmental factors in which something exists or functions. The definition of an Environment element can be further defined using EnvironmentKind.

stereotypes.name: EnvironmentalCondition
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that indicates under which environment an exhibits-relationship takes place.

stereotypes.name: EnvironmentalContext
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that indicates under which condition an measurement counts.

stereotypes.name: EnvironmentProperty
stereotypes.notes: A property of an Environment that is typed by a Condition.  The kinds of Condition that can be represented are Location, GeoPoliticalExtentType and Environment.

stereotypes.name: Evaluates
stereotypes.notes: This relation states that an evaluation criterion (FulfilmentCriterion) can be assigned to a specific acceptance criterion (FitCriterion).

stereotypes.name: Exchange
stereotypes.notes: Abstract tuple, grouping OperationalExchanges and ResourceExchanges that exchange Resources.

stereotypes.name: ExchangeItem
stereotypes.notes: An abstract grouping for elements that defines the types of elements that can be exchanged between Assets and conveyed by an Exchange.

stereotypes.name: Exhibits
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that exists between a CapableElement and a Capability that it meets under specific environmental conditions.

stereotypes.name: Expresses
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description includes the following architectures.

stereotypes.name: FieldedCapability
stereotypes.notes: An individual, fully-realized capability.

stereotypes.name: Finding
stereotypes.notes: An ascertainment made in the model, which relates to the methodology used, the subject under consideration, the tool or something else.

stereotypes.name: FitCriterion
stereotypes.notes: This element represents an acceptance criterion for a functional or non-functional requirement.

stereotypes.name: Forecast
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that specifies a transition from one Asset, Standard, Competence to another future one. It is related to an ActualEnterprisePhase to give it a temporal context.

stereotypes.name: ForecastPeriod
stereotypes.notes: Planning phase for which the forecast is valid.

stereotypes.name: FormStoredIn
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that a digital form is stored in software.

stereotypes.name: FulfilmentCriterion
stereotypes.notes: This element represents a criterion for evaluating the degree of implementation of a functional or non-functional requirement.

stereotypes.name: Function
stereotypes.notes: An Activity which is specified in the context to the ResourcePerformer (human or machine) that IsCapableToPerform it.

stereotypes.name: FunctionAction
stereotypes.notes: A call of a Function indicating that the Function is performed by a ResourceRole in a specific context.

stereotypes.name: FunctionalRequirement
stereotypes.notes: The element represents a functional requirement (what should the system / software be able to do?).

stereotypes.name: FunctionControlFlow
stereotypes.notes: An ActivityEdge that shows the flow of control between FunctionActions.

stereotypes.name: FunctionEdge
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that shows the flow of Resources (objects/data) between FunctionActions.

stereotypes.name: FunctionObjectFlow
stereotypes.notes: An ActivityEdge that shows the flow of Resources (objects/data) between FunctionActions.

stereotypes.name: FunctionSubject
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that a function uses certain resources.

stereotypes.name: GeoPoliticalExtentType
stereotypes.notes: A geospatial extent whose boundaries are defined by declaration or agreement by political parties.

stereotypes.name: GoalForActualEnterprisePhase
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which actual enterprisephase implements an enterprisegoal.

stereotypes.name: HighLevelOperationalConcept
stereotypes.notes: Describes the Resources and Locations required to meet an operational scenario from an integrated systems point of view. It is used to communicate overall quantitative and qualitative system characteristics to stakeholders

stereotypes.name: HostedOn
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that hardware (virtualized) or software is hosted on a virtualized platform or physical hardware.

stereotypes.name: Implements
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that defines how an element in the upper layer of abstraction is implemented by a semantically equivalent element (i.e. tracing the OperationalActivities to the Functions that implement them) in the lower level of abstraction.

stereotypes.name: ImplementsProtocol
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which protocol implements an architectural element.

stereotypes.name: Information
stereotypes.notes: A comment that describes the state of an item of interest in any medium or form -- and is communicated or received.

stereotypes.name: InformationElement
stereotypes.notes: An item of information that flows between OperationalPerformers and is produced and consumed by the OperationalActivities that the OperationalPerformers are capable to perform (see IsCapableToPerform).

stereotypes.name: InformationRole
stereotypes.notes: A usage of InformationElement that exists in the context of an OperationalAsset. It also allows the representation of the whole-part aggregation of InformationElements.

stereotypes.name: InteractionMessage
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that groups several types of messages used in the InteractionScenario.

stereotypes.name: InteractionRole
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents an individual participant in the InteractionScenario.

stereotypes.name: IsAccountableFor
stereotypes.notes: A relation that expresses that an OrganizationalResource is responsible for a resource, service or project in the context of an approval.

stereotypes.name: IsCapableToPerform
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that says that a capable element performs an activity or action.

stereotypes.name: IsDuplicateOf
stereotypes.notes: Relation that represents that two requirements convey the same content.

stereotypes.name: IsEquivalentToStandardElement
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that indicates that a model element corresponds to a catalog element.

stereotypes.name: IsResponsibleFor
stereotypes.notes: A relation that expresses that an OrganizationalResource is responsible for a resource, service or project.

stereotypes.name: JustifiedBy
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that an Constraint is derived from a reference (Reference, DocumentReference, SMEReference).

stereotypes.name: KnownResource
stereotypes.notes: Asserts that a known ResourcePerformer constrains the implementation of the OperationalPerformer that plays the role in the LogicalArchitecture.

stereotypes.name: Location
stereotypes.notes: A specification of the generic area in which a LocationHolder is required to be located.

stereotypes.name: LocationHolder
stereotypes.notes: Abstract type, used to group elements that are allowed to be associated with a Location.

stereotypes.name: LocationType
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which location is assigned to a location holder.

stereotypes.name: MapsToCapability
stereotypes.notes: A tuple denoting that an Activity contributes to providing a Capability.

stereotypes.name: MeasurableElement
stereotypes.notes: Abstract type, grouping elements that can be measured by applying MeasurementSets to them.

stereotypes.name: Measurement
stereotypes.notes: A property of an element representing something in the physical world, expressed in amounts of a unit of measure.

stereotypes.name: MeasurementType
stereotypes.notes: A type of a property representing something in the physical world, expressed in amounts of a unit of measure.

stereotypes.name: Metadata
stereotypes.notes: A comment that can be applied to any element in the architecture. The attributes associated with this element details the relationship between the element and its related dublinCoreElement, metaDataScheme, category and name. This allows the element to be referenced using the Semantic Web.

stereotypes.name: MilestoneDependency
stereotypes.notes: A tuple between two ActualProjectMilestones that denotes one ActualProjectMilestone follows from another.

stereotypes.name: NaturalResource
stereotypes.notes: Type of physical resource that occurs in nature.

stereotypes.name: NeedsModificationOf
stereotypes.notes: Relation stats that a project makes adjustments to a resource.

stereotypes.name: NeedsResource
stereotypes.notes: Relation stats that a project needs a resource.

stereotypes.name: NeedsService
stereotypes.notes: A relation that expresses that a project needs a service

stereotypes.name: NonfunctionalRequirement
stereotypes.notes: The element represents a non-functional requirement (how should the system / software be able to do something?).

stereotypes.name: OperationalActivity
stereotypes.notes: An Activity that captures a logical process, specified independently of how the process is carried out.

stereotypes.name: OperationalActivityAction
stereotypes.notes: A call of an OperationalActivity in the context of another OperationalActivity.

stereotypes.name: OperationalActivityEdge
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that shows the flow of Resources (objects/information) between OperationalActivityActions.

stereotypes.name: OperationalAgent
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping Operational Architecture and Operational Performer.

stereotypes.name: OperationalArchitecture
stereotypes.notes: A type used to denote a model of the Architecture, described from the Operational perspective.

stereotypes.name: OperationalArchitectureOfEnterprisePhase
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that says that in a actual enterprisephase an operational architecture is valid.

stereotypes.name: OperationalAsset
stereotypes.notes: An abstract element used to group the elements of OperationalAgent and InformationElement allowing them to own InformationRoles.

stereotypes.name: OperationalConnector
stereotypes.notes: A Connector that goes between OperationalRoles representing a need to exchange Resources. It can carry a number of OperationalExchanges.

stereotypes.name: OperationalConstraint
stereotypes.notes: A Rule governing a logical architectural element i.e. OperationalPerformer, OperationalActivity, InformationElement etc.

stereotypes.name: OperationalControlFlow
stereotypes.notes: An ActivityEdge that shows the flow of control between OperationalActivityActions.

stereotypes.name: OperationalExchange
stereotypes.notes: Asserts that a flow can exist between OperationalPerformers (i.e. flows of information, people, materiel, or energy).

stereotypes.name: OperationalExchangeItem
stereotypes.notes: An abstract grouping for elements that defines the types of elements that can be exchanged between OperationalPerformers and conveyed by an OperationalExchange.

stereotypes.name: OperationalInterface
stereotypes.notes: A declaration that specifies a contract between the OperationalPerformer it is related to, and any other OperationalPerformers it can interact with.

stereotypes.name: OperationalMessage
stereotypes.notes: Message for use in an Operational Event-Trace which carries any of the subtypes of OperationalExchange.

stereotypes.name: OperationalMessageFlow
stereotypes.notes: A ProcessMessageFlow that shows the flow of message between OperationalActivityActions of different ActivityPartitions like Pools.

stereotypes.name: OperationalMethod
stereotypes.notes: behavioral feature of a OperationalPerformer whose behavior is specified in an OperationalActivity.

stereotypes.name: OperationalObjectFlow
stereotypes.notes: An ActivityEdge that shows the flow of Resources (objects/information) between OperationalActivityActions.

stereotypes.name: OperationalParameter
stereotypes.notes: A type that represents inputs and outputs of an OperationalActivity. It is typed by an OperationalExchangeItem.

stereotypes.name: OperationalPerformer
stereotypes.notes: A logical entity that IsCapableToPerform OperationalActivities which produce, consume and process Resources.

stereotypes.name: OperationalPort
stereotypes.notes: An interaction point for an OperationalAgent through which it can interact with the outside environment and which is defined by an OperationalInterface.

stereotypes.name: OperationalRole
stereotypes.notes: Usage of a OperationalPerformer or OperationalArchitecture in the context of another OperationalPerformer or OperationalArchitecture. Creates a whole-part relationship.

stereotypes.name: OperationalSignal
stereotypes.notes: An item of information that flows between OperationalPerformers and is produced and consumed by the OperationalActivities that the OperationalPerformers are capable of performing (see IsCapableToPerform).

stereotypes.name: OperationalSignalProperty
stereotypes.notes: A property of an OperationalSignal typed by OperationalExchangeItem. It enables OperationalExchangeItem e.g. InformationElement to be passed as arguments of the OperationalSignal.

stereotypes.name: OperationalStateDescription
stereotypes.notes: A state machine describing the behavior of a OperationalPerformer, depicting how the OperationalPerformer responds to various events and the actions.

stereotypes.name: Organization
stereotypes.notes: A group of OrganizationalResources (Persons, Posts, Organizations and Responsibilities) associated for a particular purpose.

stereotypes.name: OrganizationalResource
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type for Organization, Person Post and Responsibility.

stereotypes.name: OriginatesFrom
stereotypes.notes: Relation that derives an element in the architectural model from a reference (Reference, DocumentReference, SMEReference).

stereotypes.name: OwnedMilestone
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that expresses that actual project has a actual milestone.

stereotypes.name: OwnsActualMeasurementSet
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which actual measurement set an element owns.

stereotypes.name: OwnsMeasurement
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which measurement or measurement type an element owns.

stereotypes.name: OwnsProcess
stereotypes.notes: A dependency relationship denoting that an ActualOrganizationResource owns an OperationalActivity.

stereotypes.name: PaperForm
stereotypes.notes: Form is a digitized or digitizable document, for example a scanned document.

stereotypes.name: PartOfCatalogue
stereotypes.notes: This relation states that a category (RequirementCategory) belongs to a requirements catalog (RequirementCatalogue).

stereotypes.name: PartOfCategory
stereotypes.notes: This relation states that his functional or non-functional requirement belongs to a category (RequirementCategory) of the requirements catalog.

stereotypes.name: PerformsInContext
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that says that a role performs an activity or action. It indicates that the action can be carried out by the role when used in a specific context or configuration.

stereotypes.name: Person
stereotypes.notes: A type of a human being used to define the characteristics that need to be described for ActualPersons (e.g. properties such as address, telephone number, nationality, etc).

stereotypes.name: PhysicalArchitectureOfEnterprisePhase
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual enterprise phase has resource architectures.

stereotypes.name: PhysicalLocation
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that a location holder operates in an actual location.

stereotypes.name: PhysicalResource
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type defining physical resources (i.e. OrganizationalResource, ResourceArtifact and NaturalResource).

stereotypes.name: Post
stereotypes.notes: A type of job title or position that a person can fill (e.g. Lawyer, Solution Architect, Machine Operator or Chief Executive Officer).

stereotypes.name: PostRole
stereotypes.notes: A usage of a post in the context of another OrganizationalResource. Creates a whole-part relationship.

stereotypes.name: ProblemDomain
stereotypes.notes: A property associated with a logical architecture, used to specify the scope of the problem.

stereotypes.name: ProcessEdge
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents a behavior or process (i.e. a Function or OperationalActivity) that can be performed by a Performer.

stereotypes.name: ProcessGeneralization
stereotypes.notes: A ProcessGeneralization is a taxonomic relationship between a more general Process and a more specific Process.

stereotypes.name: ProcessMessageFlow
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that shows the flow of message between different ActivityPartitions like Pools.

stereotypes.name: ProcessOperation
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents a behavior or process (i.e. a Function or OperationalActivity) that can be performed by a Performer.

stereotypes.name: ProcessParameter
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents a behavior or process (i.e. a Function or OperationalActivity) that can be performed by a Performer.

stereotypes.name: ProcessUsage
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents a behavior or process (i.e. a Function or OperationalActivity) that can be performed by a Performer or Role.

stereotypes.name: Project
stereotypes.notes: A type that describes types of time-limited endeavours that are required to meet one or more Capability needs.

stereotypes.name: ProjectMilestone
stereotypes.notes: A type of event in a Project by which progress is measured.

stereotypes.name: ProjectMilestoneRole
stereotypes.notes: The role played by a ProjectMilestone in the context of a Project.

stereotypes.name: ProjectMilestoneToProjectTheme
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which project theme is handled by which project milestone.

stereotypes.name: ProjectProvidesFunction
stereotypes.notes: Relation stats that a project realizes a function.

stereotypes.name: ProjectRole
stereotypes.notes: Usage of a Project in the context of another Project. Creates a whole-part relationship.

stereotypes.name: ProjectSequence
stereotypes.notes: A tuple between two ActualProjects that denotes one ActualProject cannot start before the previous ActualProject is finished.

stereotypes.name: ProjectStatus
stereotypes.notes: The status (i.e. level of progress) of a ProjectTheme for an ActualProject at the time of the ActualProjectMilestone.

stereotypes.name: ProjectSupportActivity
stereotypes.notes: Relation stats that a project supports an activity.

stereotypes.name: ProjectTheme
stereotypes.notes: A property of a ProjectMilestone that captures an aspect by which the progress of ActualProjects may be measured.

stereotypes.name: PropertySet
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping architectural elements that can own Measurements.

stereotypes.name: PropertySetGeneralisation
stereotypes.notes: A PropertySetGeneralization is a taxonomic relationship between a more general PropertySet and a more specific PropertySet.

stereotypes.name: Protocol
stereotypes.notes: A Standard for communication over a network. Protocols may be composite, represented as a ProtocolStack made up of ProtocolLayers.

stereotypes.name: ProtocolImplementation
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping architectural elements that can implement Protocols.

stereotypes.name: ProtocolLayer
stereotypes.notes: Usage of a Protocol in the context of another Protocol. Creates a whole-part relationship.

stereotypes.name: Protocolstack
stereotypes.notes: A sub type of Protocol that contains the ProtocolLayers, defining a complete stack.

stereotypes.name: ProvidedServiceLevel
stereotypes.notes: A sub type of ActualService that details a specific service level delivered by the provider.

stereotypes.name: Provides
stereotypes.notes: Asserts that a operational agent provides a service.

stereotypes.name: ProvidesCompetence
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that asserts that an ActualOrganizationalResource provides a specific set of Competencies.

stereotypes.name: ProvidesServiceFunction
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that expresses that a service function is provided by an interface.

stereotypes.name: RatifiedStandards
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual organization releases a standard.

stereotypes.name: RealiseRequirement
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that a functional or non-functional requirement is realized through this element.

stereotypes.name: RealizedDesiredEffect
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that expresses which connector DesiredEffect the connector AchievedEffect realizes.

stereotypes.name: RealizesRecommendation
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that a Recommendation is realized through this element.

stereotypes.name: RealizingAchievedEffect
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that expresses which connector AchievedEffect realizes the connector DesiredEffect.

stereotypes.name: Recommendation
stereotypes.notes: Need for action from a finding.

stereotypes.name: Reference
stereotypes.notes: Element describes all types of references.

stereotypes.name: RefersTo
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that assigns a finding to a recommendation.

stereotypes.name: Refines
stereotypes.notes: Relation that represents a refinement of a requirement by another requirement.

stereotypes.name: Replaces
stereotypes.notes: Relation that represents a replacement of a requirement with another requirement.

stereotypes.name: ReplaceStandardElement
stereotypes.notes: Relation that represents a replacement of a standard element with another standard element

stereotypes.name: RequiredEnvironment
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that a location holder operates under specific environmental conditions.

stereotypes.name: RequiredResource
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that indicates which resources a project milestone requires

stereotypes.name: RequiredServiceLevel
stereotypes.notes: A sub type of ActualService that details a specific service level required of the provider.

stereotypes.name: RequirementCatalogue
stereotypes.notes: Element represents a catalog of requirements, which consists of different categories (RequirementCategory) of functional and non-functional requirements.

stereotypes.name: RequirementCategory
stereotypes.notes: Element represents a category of a catalog of requirements.

stereotypes.name: Requires
stereotypes.notes: Relation that represents that a requirement assumes another requirement.

stereotypes.name: RequiresCompetence
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that asserts that an ActualOrganizationalResource is required to have a specific set of Competencies.

stereotypes.name: Resource
stereotypes.notes: Abstract element grouping for all elements that can be conveyed by an Exchange.

stereotypes.name: ResourceArchitecture
stereotypes.notes: A type used to denote a model of the Architecture, described from the ResourcePerformer perspective.

stereotypes.name: ResourceArtifact
stereotypes.notes: A type of man-made object that contains no human beings (i.e. satellite, radio, petrol, gasoline, etc.).

stereotypes.name: ResourceAsset
stereotypes.notes: An abstract element used to group the elements of ResourcePerformer and DataElement allowing them to own DataRoles

stereotypes.name: ResourceConnector
stereotypes.notes: A channel for exchange between two ResourceRoles.

stereotypes.name: ResourceConstraint
stereotypes.notes: A rule governing the structural or functional aspects of an implementation.

stereotypes.name: ResourceDependency
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that is a dependency of a resource on a resource.

stereotypes.name: ResourceExchange
stereotypes.notes: Asserts that a flow can exist between ResourcePerformers (i.e. flows of data, people, material, or energy).

stereotypes.name: ResourceExchangeItem
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping elements that defines the types of elements that can be exchanged between ResourcePerformers and conveyed by a ResourceExchange.

stereotypes.name: ResourceInterface
stereotypes.notes: A declaration that specifies a contract between the ResourcePerformers it is related to and any other ResourcePerformers it can interact with. It is also intended to be an implementation of a specification of an Interface in the Business and/or Service layer.

stereotypes.name: ResourceMessage
stereotypes.notes: Message for use in an Resource Event-Trace which carries any of the subtypes of ResourceExchange.

stereotypes.name: ResourceMethod
stereotypes.notes: A behavioral feature of a ResourcePerformer whose behavior is specified in a Function.

stereotypes.name: ResourceMitigation
stereotypes.notes: A set of measures intended to implement an OperationalMitigation. Comprises a subset of activities that are performed in mitigation of the risk to protect the asset that is the subject of risk (ResourceRole) at the physical level. In the case of a Risk applicable to security, the form of activity is a SecurityControl or an EnhancedSecurityControl, otherwise it is a Function.

stereotypes.name: ResourceParameter
stereotypes.notes: A type that represents inputs and outputs of an Function. It is typed by a ResourceInteractionItem.

stereotypes.name: ResourcePerformer
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping elements that can be the subject of a SecurityConstraint (there are currently no security viewpoints in the NAF).

stereotypes.name: ResourcePort
stereotypes.notes: An interaction point for a ResourcePerformer through which it can interact with the outside environment and which is defined by a ResourceInterface.

stereotypes.name: ResourceRole
stereotypes.notes: Usage of a ResourcePerformer in the context of another ResourcePerformer. Creates a whole-part relationship.

stereotypes.name: ResourceSignal
stereotypes.notes: A property of an element representing something in the physical world, expressed in amounts of a unit of measure.

stereotypes.name: ResourceSignalProperty
stereotypes.notes: A property of an ResourceSignal typed by ResourceExchangeItem. It enables ResourceExchangeItem e.g. DataElement to be passed as arguments of the ResourceSignal.

stereotypes.name: ResourceStateDescription
stereotypes.notes: A state machine describing the behavior of a ResourcePerformer, depicting how the ResourcePerformer responds to various events and the actions.

stereotypes.name: ResourceToServiceDependency
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that a resource is dependent on a service.

stereotypes.name: Responsibility
stereotypes.notes: The type of duty required of a Person or Organization.

stereotypes.name: Responsible
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that a project is responsible for a service or a material resource.

stereotypes.name: ResultsFrom
stereotypes.notes: Relationship expresses that an element of architecture is the reason for a finding.

stereotypes.name: Rule
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type for all types of constraint (i.e. an OperationalConstraint could detail the rules of accountancy best practice).

stereotypes.name: SameAs
stereotypes.notes: A tuple that asserts that two elements refer to the same real-world thing.

stereotypes.name: Satisfy
stereotypes.notes: This relation states that an constraint affects an element.

stereotypes.name: SecurityConstraint
stereotypes.notes: A type of rule that captures a formal statement to define security laws, regulations, guidances, and policy. Element is not used in the current version of the framework and reserved for future developments.

stereotypes.name: SecurityEnclave
stereotypes.notes: Collection of information systems connected by one or more internal networks under the control of a single authority and security policy. The systems may be structured by physical proximity or by function, independent of location.  Element is not used in the current version of the framework and reserved for future developments.

stereotypes.name: SecurityProcess
stereotypes.notes: The security-related procedure that satisfies the security control requirement. Element is not used in the current version of the framework and reserved for future developments.

stereotypes.name: ServiceClassification
stereotypes.notes: Relation is used to show that two services have a relationship in the sense of a taxonomy.

stereotypes.name: ServiceConnector
stereotypes.notes: A channel for exchange between two ServiceSpecifications. Where one acts as the consumer of the other.

stereotypes.name: ServiceDependency
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that is a dependency of a service on a service, operational node or resource.

stereotypes.name: ServiceFunction
stereotypes.notes: An Activity that describes the abstract behavior of ServiceSpecifications, regardless of the actual implementation.

stereotypes.name: ServiceFunctionAction
stereotypes.notes: A call of a ServiceFunction in the context of another ServiceFunction.

stereotypes.name: ServiceInterface
stereotypes.notes: A contract that defines the ServiceMethods and ServiceMessageHandlers that the ServiceSpecification realizes.

stereotypes.name: ServiceMessage
stereotypes.notes: Message for use in a Service Event-Trace.

stereotypes.name: ServiceMethod
stereotypes.notes: A behavioral feature of a ServiceSpecification whose behavior is specified in a ServiceFunction.

stereotypes.name: ServiceParameter
stereotypes.notes: A type that represents inputs and outputs of a ServiceFunction, represents inputs and outputs of a ServiceSpecification.

stereotypes.name: ServicePolicy
stereotypes.notes: A constraint governing the use of one or more ServiceSpecifications.

stereotypes.name: ServicePort
stereotypes.notes: An interaction point for a ServiceSpecification through which it can interact with the outside environment and which is defined by a ServiceInterface.

stereotypes.name: ServiceProvision
stereotypes.notes: An assertion that a Resource delivers a Service to a specified ServiceLevel.

stereotypes.name: ServiceSpecification
stereotypes.notes: The specification of a set of functionality provided one element for the use of others.

stereotypes.name: ServiceSpecificationGeneralization
stereotypes.notes: A ServiceSpecificationGeneralization is a taxonomic relationship between a more general ServiceSpecification and a more specific ServiceSpecification.

stereotypes.name: ServiceSpecificationRole
stereotypes.notes: An assertion that a ServiceSecification calls upon another ServiceSpecification in order to deliver its stated functionality.

stereotypes.name: ServiceStateDescription
stereotypes.notes: A state machine descripting the behavior of a ServiceSpecification, depicting how the ServiceSpecification responds to various events and the actions.

stereotypes.name: SMEReference
stereotypes.notes: Element stands for a result of a workshop or expert knowledge.

stereotypes.name: Software
stereotypes.notes: A sub-type of ResourceArtifact that specifies an executable computer program.

stereotypes.name: Stakeholder
stereotypes.notes: individual, team, organization, or classes thereof, having an interest in an EnterprisePhase [ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011].

stereotypes.name: StakeholderConcern
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which concern a stakeholder has.

stereotypes.name: Standard
stereotypes.notes: A ratified and peer-reviewed specification that is used to guide or constrain the architecture. A Standard may be applied to any element in the architecture.

stereotypes.name: StandardOperationalActivity
stereotypes.notes: A sub-type of OperationalActivity that is a standard operating procedure.

stereotypes.name: StateDescription
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type that represents a state machine (i.e. an OperationalStateDescription or ResourceStateDescription), depicting how the Asset responds to various events and the actions.

stereotypes.name: StatementTask
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual enterprise phase fulfills a actual enduring task.

stereotypes.name: StemsFrom
stereotypes.notes: Relationship that states that one requirement stems from another.

stereotypes.name: StoredIn
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that a digital form or data is stored in software.

stereotypes.name: StrategicConstraint
stereotypes.notes: A Rule governing a capability.

stereotypes.name: SubjectOfForecast
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping elements that can be the subject of a Forecast.

stereotypes.name: SubjectOfOperationalConstraint
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping elements that can be the subject of an OperationalConstraint.

stereotypes.name: SubjectOfResourceConstraint
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping elements that can be the subject of a ResourceConstraint.

stereotypes.name: SubjectOfSecurityConstraint
stereotypes.notes: An abstract grouping of elements that can be the subject of a SecurityConstraint. Element is not used in the current version of the framework and reserved for future developments.

stereotypes.name: SubOrganization
stereotypes.notes: A type of a human being used to define the characteristics that need to be described for ActualPersons (e.g. properties such as address, telephone number, nationality, etc).

stereotypes.name: SuccessorOf
stereotypes.notes: A relationship between two elements that indicates that one element is the successor of the other.

stereotypes.name: System
stereotypes.notes: An integrated set of elements, subsystems, or assemblies that accomplish a defined objective. These elements include products (hardware, software, firmware), processes, people, information, techniques, facilities, services, and other support elements (INCOSE SE Handbook V4, 2015).

stereotypes.name: Technology
stereotypes.notes: A sub type of ResourceArtifact that indicates a technology domain, i.e. nuclear, mechanical, electronic, mobile telephony etc.

stereotypes.name: TemporalPart
stereotypes.notes: A current or future state of the wholeLifeEnterprise or another EnterprisePhase.

stereotypes.name: ToBeRealizedBy
stereotypes.notes: Relation states that a functional or non-functional requirement should be realized through this element.

stereotypes.name: UAFElement
stereotypes.notes: Abstract super type for all of the UAF elements. It provides a way for all of the UAF elements to have a common set of properties.

stereotypes.name: VersionedElement
stereotypes.notes: An abstract type grouping ResourcePerformer and ServiceSpecification that allows VersionOfConfiguration to be related to ActualProjectMilestones.

stereotypes.name: VersionOfConfiguration
stereotypes.notes: A property of a WholeLifeConfiguration, used in version control of a VersionedElement. It asserts that a VersionedElement is a version of a WholeLifeConfiguration.

stereotypes.name: VersionReleased
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual project milestone releases an versioned element.

stereotypes.name: VersionSuccession
stereotypes.notes: A tuple between two  VersionOfConfigurations that denotes that one VersionOfConfiguration follows from another.

stereotypes.name: VersionWithdrawn
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual project milestone withdraws an versioned element.

stereotypes.name: View
stereotypes.notes: An architecture view expresses the architecture of the system-of-interest in accordance with an architecture viewpoint (or simply, viewpoint). [ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011(E)].

stereotypes.name: Viewpoint
stereotypes.notes: An architecture viewpoint frames (to formulate or construct in a particular style or language) one or more concerns. A concern can be framed by more than one viewpoint.  [ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011(E)].

stereotypes.name: ViewpointsInArchitecturalDescription
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description includes the following viewpoints.

stereotypes.name: ViewpointToStakeholder
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which stakeholder needs viewpoint.

stereotypes.name: ViewsInArchitecturalDescription
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description includes the following views.

stereotypes.name: VisionForActualEnterprisePhase
stereotypes.notes: A relationship that expresses which actual enterprisephase implements an enterprisevision.

stereotypes.name: WholeLifeConfiguration
stereotypes.notes: A set of VersionedElements.

stereotypes.name: WholeLifeEnterprise
stereotypes.notes: A WholeLifeEnterprise is a purposeful endeavor of any size involving people, organizations and supporting systems. It is made up of TemporalParts and StructuralParts.

stereotypes.name: A1 - Meta-Data Definitions
stereotypes.notes: Architectures, particularly large ones, usually require meta-data tags to aid with searching and discovery.

stereotypes.name: A2 - Architecture Products
stereotypes.notes: The A2 Viewpoint specifies the structure of an architecture, and the products that describe the architecture. Each product may correspond to an architecture view. This viewpoint also traces the architectures onto the Enterprise Phases they correspond to (see also C2  Enterprise Vision) and identifies the key stakeholders, their concerns and the products that address those concerns (from ISO/IEC/IEEE Standards).

stereotypes.name: A3 - Architecture Correspondence
stereotypes.notes: ISO/IEC/IEEE42010 introduces the idea of architecture correspondence and correspondence rules. Quoting from ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010; A correspondence defines a relation between AD (Architecture Description) elements. Correspondences are used to express architecture relations of interest within an architecture description (or between architecture descriptions). Correspondences can be governed by correspondence rules. Correspondence rules are used to enforce relations within an architecture description (or between architecture descriptions).

stereotypes.name: A4 - Methodology Used
stereotypes.notes: The A4 Viewpoint specifies the methodology used for the architecting activities. This methodology is described in NAFv4 Chapter 2. The content of the A4 viewpoint can also be modeled in the A1 viewpoint.

stereotypes.name: A5 - Architecture Status
stereotypes.notes: Since NAFv3.0, it has been possible to assign version numbers to views and specify their approval dates. In NAFv4.0, this is integrated with the meta-models generic project and milestone approach so that architecture releases are tracked against the architecture delivery project. The content of the A5 viewpoint can also be modeled in the A1 viewpoint.

stereotypes.name: A6 - Architecture Version
stereotypes.notes: Where the A5 Viewpoint shows the current version number and approval status for the architecture, the A6 Viewpoint shows the complete history of the architecture.

stereotypes.name: A7 - Architecture Compliance
stereotypes.notes: The A7 Viewpoint gives the overall specification of architecture meta-data.

stereotypes.name: A8 - Standards
stereotypes.notes: The A8 Viewpoint encompasses both technical and non-technical standards. The standards specified in the A8 view can be applied across the architecture to a variety of structural and behavioural elements. Standards are essential to the coherent running of businesses and to the delivery of reliable, interoperable systems.

stereotypes.name: Ar - Architecture Roadmap
stereotypes.notes: The Ar Viewpoint shows the history of the architecture project as well as its future direction.

stereotypes.name: C1 - Capability Taxonomy
stereotypes.notes: The C1 Viewpoint specifies all the capabilities that are referenced throughout one or more architectures  i.e. one C1 may provide the definitive list of capabilities for a number of logical and resource architectures. The capabilities may be organised into specialisation hierarchies (taxonomies). Measures of Effectiveness (MoE) may be specified for each capability. Note that MoEs are inherited down a capability taxonomy.

stereotypes.name: C2 - Enterprise Vision
stereotypes.notes: The purpose of the C2 Viewpoint is to provide a strategic context for the capabilities described in the architecture and to specify the scope for the architecture. The C2 Viewpoint is high-level and describes the vision, goals, enduring tasks and capabilities using terminology that is easily understood by non-technical readers.

stereotypes.name: C3 - Capability Dependencies
stereotypes.notes: The C3 Viewpoint is intended to provide a means of analysing the dependencies between capabilities and between capability clusters. The composition of capabilities (into clusters) is logical and the purpose of the clusters is to guide enterprise management.

stereotypes.name: C4 - Standard Processes
stereotypes.notes: The C4 Viewpoint specifies Standard Operational Activities that can be re-used across multiple logical architectures (e.g. in L4, Logical Activities).

stereotypes.name: C5 - Effects
stereotypes.notes: The purpose of the C5 Viewpoint is to describe the operational effect of the capabilities, activities and services according to the expected goals. The C5 Viewpoint is high-level description that should be easily understood by non-technical readers.

stereotypes.name: C7 - Performance Parameters
stereotypes.notes: In the C7 Viewpoint the capability requirements (and existing capabilities) can be expressed in terms of Measures of Effectiveness (MoEs). These are high-level metrics used to judge the level of capability.

stereotypes.name: C8 - Planning Assumptions
stereotypes.notes: The C8 Viewpoint is concerned with identification and description of assumptions that have been made for the implementation of capabilities. Assumptions can be expressed by means of requirements.

stereotypes.name: Cr - Capability Roadmap
stereotypes.notes: The Cr Viewpont supports the Capability Audit process by providing a method to identify gaps or duplications in capability provision. Cr indicates capability increments, which are derived from delivery milestones within acquisition projects.

stereotypes.name: L1 - Node Types
stereotypes.notes: The L1 Viewpoint defines all of the Nodes that will appear in a Logical Architecture. Nodes are elements of capability assembled and orchestrated in the Logical Architecture (see L2 - Logical Scenario and L4 - Logical Activities views). The levels of capability provided by each node are expressed as Measures of Performance (MoPs) and these may be dependent on the environments in which the Node is required to operate.

stereotypes.name: L2 - Logical Scenario
stereotypes.notes: The L2 Viewpoint specifies Nodes (elements of capability) in context of each other. The context is usually expressed in terms of the information that flows between the nodes (e.g. the information flow requirements between capabilities in a given scenario) but may also be flows of materiel, human resource or energy.

stereotypes.name: L3 - Node Interactions
stereotypes.notes: L3 is used to provide further detail of the interoperability requirements associated with the operational capability of interest. The focus is on logical flows that cross the capability boundary. Although the primary purpose of the L3 Viewpoint is to specify information exchanges, the L3 may also list flows of materiel, energy and human resources.

stereotypes.name: L4 - Logical Activities
stereotypes.notes: The L4 Viewpoint describes the operational activities that are being conducted within the mission or scenario. These activities are defined at a logical, solution-neutral level so as to enable different solutions in the physical layer. The L4 Viewpoint describes the activities associated with the logical architecture, as well as the:

stereotypes.name: L5 - Logical States
stereotypes.notes: The L5 Viewpoint specifies the typical states a node may have and the possible transitions between those states (i.e. changes of state). Triggers for state changes may also be defined. Actions may be associated with a given state or with the transition between states in response to stimuli (e.g. triggers and events).

stereotypes.name: L6 - Logical Sequence
stereotypes.notes: Operational Event-Trace Descriptions, sometimes called sequence diagrams, event scenarios or timing diagrams, allow the tracing of interactions between nodes in a scenario or critical sequence of events. The node interactions usually correspond to flows of information but may describe flows of energy, materiel or people specified in the L2, Logical Scenario.

stereotypes.name: L7 - Information Model
stereotypes.notes: The L7 Viewpoint is used to document the business information. It describes the information that can be exchanged along the logical flows in the architecture, specified in L3 Node Interactions.

stereotypes.name: L8 - Logical Constraints
stereotypes.notes: The L8 Viewpoint is used to constrain the logical architecture without forcing a particular solution. L8 is used for rules which are not expressed as behavioural models, interactions or measures of effectiveness, i.e. they are textual statements of requirements that constrain the architecture.

stereotypes.name: Lr - Lines of Development
stereotypes.notes: The Lr Viewpoint is primarily intended to support the acquisition process across multiple projects or programmes, highlighting dependencies the logical dependencies between capabilities, projects and the integration of all lines of development to achieve a successfully integrated military capability. Use of the Lr Viewpoint should support the management of capability delivery and be aligned with Cr, Capability Roadmap.

stereotypes.name: L2-L3 - Logical Concept
stereotypes.notes: The L2-L3 Viewpoint is concerned with providing an executive level, scenario-based communication of the architecture purpose, scope and content.

stereotypes.name: P1 - Resource Types
stereotypes.notes: The P1 Viewpoint collects together all the Resource Types in the architecture together with a depiction of their performance characteristics. P1 also provides a summary of the technologies and competencies that impact on the Resources that constitute the architecture.

stereotypes.name: P2 - Resource Structure
stereotypes.notes: The P2 Viewpoint links together the operational and physical architecture viewpoints by depicting how types of Resource are structured and interact to realize the logical architecture specified in L2, Logical Scenario. The P2 Viewpoint may represent the realization of a requirement specified in a L2 (i.e. in a to-be architecture) and so there may be many alternative Resource viewpoint suites that could realize the operational requirement. Alternatively, in an as-is architecture, a L2 may just be a simplified, logical representation of the P2 Viewpoint to allow communication of key information flows to non-technical stakeholders.

stereotypes.name: P3 - Resource Connectivity
stereotypes.notes: The networks and pathways documented in a P3 Viewpoint represent the physical implementation of the logical flows identified in a L2, Logical Scenario, or L3, Node Interactions View.

stereotypes.name: P4 - Resource Functions
stereotypes.notes: The Functionality Description provides detailed information regarding the allocation of functions to resources, and flows between Resource Functions. The P4 Viewpoint is the Physical Resource counterpart to the L4 Logical Activities Viewpoint.

stereotypes.name: P5 - Resource States
stereotypes.notes: The P5 Viewpoint identifies the states a Resource can be, the allowable changes between those states, and the stimuli (e.g. triggers and events) that cause the state changes.

stereotypes.name: P6 - Resource Sequence
stereotypes.notes: The P6 Viewpoint is valuable for moving to the next level of detail from the initial solution design, to help define a sequence of functions and Resource Interactions, and to ensure that each participating Resource or Port has the necessary information, at the right time, in order to perform its assigned functionality.

stereotypes.name: P7 -  Data Model
stereotypes.notes: The P7 Viewpoint is one of the architectural products closest to actual system design in the NAF. It is used to describe how the information represented in the L7 Logical Data Model Viewpoint is implemented.

stereotypes.name: P8 - Resource Constraints
stereotypes.notes: The P8 Viewpoint describes constraints on the Resources, Resource Functions, data and communications that make up a Physical Architecture.

stereotypes.name: Pr - Configuration Management
stereotypes.notes: The Pr Viewpoint provides an overview of how Resource Assets change over time (note that NAF v3.1 only allowed for Capability Configurations whereas now this is opened up to all Resource Types). It shows the structure of different versions of Resource Assets (usually Capability Configurations or Service Implementations) mapped against a timeline.

stereotypes.name: L4-P4 - Activity To Function Mapping
stereotypes.notes: The L4-P4 Viewpoint depicts the mapping of Resource Functions (and optionally, the resources that provide them) to operational activities and/or service functions. For operational activities it thus identifies the transformation of an operational need into a purposeful action performed by a system or solution. For service functions it provides the link between the services used at the operational level and the specific Resource Functions provided by the resources supporting the services.

stereotypes.name: S1 - Service Taxonomy
stereotypes.notes: The purpose of the S1 Viewpoint is to provide a governance structure for a Service-Oriented Architecture. Along with S3, Service Interfaces, it specifies a standard library of service specifications for an enterprise, to which service implementers are expected to conform.

stereotypes.name: S2 - Service Structure
stereotypes.notes: The S2 Viewpoint is concerned with identification and description of how services are structured to create a higher-aggregated service. To provide highlevel views, dependencies to other services, nodes and resources as well as service interfaces and service functions can be represented.

stereotypes.name: S3 - Service Interfaces
stereotypes.notes: The S3 Viewpoint is concerned with the identification and definition of service interfaces.

stereotypes.name: S4 - Service Functions
stereotypes.notes: The S4 Viewpoint is the key behavioural specification for services. Equivalent in nature to L4, Logical Activities and P4, Resources Functions, it specifies a set of functions that a service implementation is expected to perform. Implementation of that behaviour is represented in P4, Resource Functions, and L4-P4, Activity to Function Mapping.

stereotypes.name: S5 - Service States
stereotypes.notes: The S5 Viewpoint is a specification of the allowable states of a service, and the possible transitions between them. This specification constrains how implementations of the service will behave.  It is, though, generally considered a good practice to make services stateless - i.e. consumers of a service are not aware of what state the service is in.

stereotypes.name: S6 - Service Interactions
stereotypes.notes: Service Interaction Descriptions, sometimes called sequence diagrams, event scenarios or timing diagrams, allow the tracing of interactions between services in a composition or critical sequence of events.

stereotypes.name: S7 - Service Interface Parameters
stereotypes.notes: Specifies the interfaces that a service provides and uses, defines which services are compatible with which other services.

stereotypes.name: S8 - Service Policy
stereotypes.notes: The S8 Viewpoint specifies constraints against services to which implementations must conform.

stereotypes.name: Sr - Service Roadmap
stereotypes.notes: The Sr Viewpoint supports the Service Audit process by providing a method to identify gaps or duplications in service provision. Sr indicates service lifetime evolutions, which are derived from delivery milestones within acquisition projects.

stereotypes.name: C1-S1 - Capability to Service Mapping
stereotypes.notes: A C1-S1 Viewpoint presents a simple mapping of services to capabilities, showing which services contribute to which capability.

stereotypes.name: R2 - Requirement Catalogue
stereotypes.notes: The R2 represents a catalog of requirements in the architectural model. For this purpose, categories can be created in which the functional and non-functional requirements can be grouped.

stereotypes.name: R3 - Requirement Dependencies
stereotypes.notes: The R3 is used to show dependencies between different requirements.

stereotypes.name: R7 - Requirement Derivation
stereotypes.notes: The R7 assigns functional and non-functional requirements to the demanding architectural elements. In addition, information about the planned realization can be shown.

stereotypes.name: R8 - Requirement Fulfilment
stereotypes.notes: The R8 is used to determine and map acceptance and evaluation criteria for the individual functional and non-functional requirements.

stereotypes.name: Rr - Requirement Realization
stereotypes.notes: In the Rr, requirements are assigned to the realizing architectural elements.

viewpoints.name: AssetRole
viewpoints.notes: AssetRole as applied to Security views, an abstract element that indicates the type of elements  that can be considered as a subject for security analysis in the particular context (currently no secur

viewpoints.name: CompliesViewpoint
viewpoints.notes: Relationship that expresses that a view has been created according to the specifications of a viewpoint.

viewpoints.name: ConcernForViewpoint
viewpoints.notes: A relationship that expresses which concerns are covered by viewpoint.

viewpoints.name: ResourcePerformer
viewpoints.notes: An abstract type grouping elements that can be the subject of a SecurityConstraint (there are currently no security viewpoints in the NAF).

viewpoints.name: View
viewpoints.notes: An architecture view expresses the architecture of the system-of-interest in accordance with an architecture viewpoint (or simply, viewpoint). [ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011(E)].

viewpoints.name: Viewpoint
viewpoints.notes: An architecture viewpoint frames (to formulate or construct in a particular style or language) one or more concerns. A concern can be framed by more than one viewpoint.  [ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011(E)].

viewpoints.name: ViewpointsInArchitecturalDescription
viewpoints.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description includes the following viewpoints.

viewpoints.name: ViewpointToStakeholder
viewpoints.notes: A relationship that expresses which stakeholder needs viewpoint.

viewpoints.name: NAFv4-ADMBw Architecture Foundation Viewpoints
viewpoints.notes: NAFv4-ADMBw Architecture Foundation Viewpoints

viewpoints.name: A2 - Architecture Products
viewpoints.notes: The A2 Viewpoint specifies the structure of an architecture, and the products that describe the architecture. Each product may correspond to an architecture view. This viewpoint also traces the archit

viewpoints.name: A4 - Methodology Used
viewpoints.notes: The A4 Viewpoint specifies the methodology used for the architecting activities. This methodology is described in NAFv4 Chapter 2. The content of the A4 viewpoint can also be modeled in the A1 viewpoi

viewpoints.name: A5 - Architecture Status
viewpoints.notes: Since NAFv3.0, it has been possible to assign version numbers to views and specify their approval dates. In NAFv4.0, this is integrated with the meta-models generic project and milestone approach so

viewpoints.name: A6 - Architecture Version
viewpoints.notes: Where the A5 Viewpoint shows the current version number and approval status for the architecture, the A6 Viewpoint shows the complete history of the architecture.

viewpoints.name: A7 - Architecture Compliance
viewpoints.notes: The A7 Viewpoint gives the overall specification of architecture meta-data.

viewpoints.name: A8 - Standards
viewpoints.notes: The A8 Viewpoint encompasses both technical and non-technical standards. The standards specified in the A8 view can be applied across the architecture to a variety of structural and behavioural elemen

viewpoints.name: Ar - Architecture Roadmap
viewpoints.notes: The Ar Viewpoint shows the history of the architecture project as well as its future direction.

viewpoints.name: NAFv4-ADMBw Concept Viewpoints
viewpoints.notes: NAFv4-ADMBw Concept Viewpoints

viewpoints.name: C1 - Capability Taxonomy
viewpoints.notes: The C1 Viewpoint specifies all the capabilities that are referenced throughout one or more architectures  i.e. one C1 may provide the definitive list of capabilities for a number of logical and resou

viewpoints.name: C2 - Enterprise Vision
viewpoints.notes: The purpose of the C2 Viewpoint is to provide a strategic context for the capabilities described in the architecture and to specify the scope for the architecture. The C2 Viewpoint is high-level and d

viewpoints.name: C3 - Capability Dependencies
viewpoints.notes: The C3 Viewpoint is intended to provide a means of analysing the dependencies between capabilities and between capability clusters. The composition of capabilities (into clusters) is logical and the p

viewpoints.name: C4 - Standard Processes
viewpoints.notes: The C4 Viewpoint specifies Standard Operational Activities that can be re-used across multiple logical architectures (e.g. in L4, Logical Activities).

viewpoints.name: C5 - Effects
viewpoints.notes: The purpose of the C5 Viewpoint is to describe the operational effect of the capabilities, activities and services according to the expected goals. The C5 Viewpoint is high-level description that shou

viewpoints.name: C7 - Performance Parameters
viewpoints.notes: In the C7 Viewpoint the capability requirements (and existing capabilities) can be expressed in terms of Measures of Effectiveness (MoEs). These are high-level metrics used to judge the level of capab

viewpoints.name: C8 - Planning Assumptions
viewpoints.notes: The C8 Viewpoint is concerned with identification and description of assumptions that have been made for the implementation of capabilities. Assumptions can be expressed by means of requirements.

viewpoints.name: NAFv4-ADMBw Logical Specification Viewpoints
viewpoints.notes: NAFv4-ADMBw Logical Specification Viewpoints

viewpoints.name: L1 - Node Types
viewpoints.notes: The L1 Viewpoint defines all of the Nodes that will appear in a Logical Architecture. Nodes are elements of capability assembled and orchestrated in the Logical Architecture (see L2 - Logical Scenario

viewpoints.name: L2 - Logical Scenario
viewpoints.notes: The L2 Viewpoint specifies Nodes (elements of capability) in context of each other. The context is usually expressed in terms of the information that flows between the nodes (e.g. the information flow

viewpoints.name: L3 - Node Interactions
viewpoints.notes: L3 is used to provide further detail of the interoperability requirements associated with the operational capability of interest. The focus is on logical flows that cross the capability boundary. Alth

viewpoints.name: L4 - Logical Activities
viewpoints.notes: The L4 Viewpoint describes the operational activities that are being conducted within the mission or scenario. These activities are defined at a logical, solution-neutral level so as to enable differe

viewpoints.name: L5 - Logical States
viewpoints.notes: The L5 Viewpoint specifies the typical states a node may have and the possible transitions between those states (i.e. changes of state). Triggers for state changes may also be defined. Actions may be

viewpoints.name: L7 - Information Model
viewpoints.notes: The L7 Viewpoint is used to document the business information. It describes the information that can be exchanged along the logical flows in the architecture, specified in L3 Node Interactions.

viewpoints.name: L8 - Logical Constraints
viewpoints.notes: The L8 Viewpoint is used to constrain the logical architecture without forcing a particular solution. L8 is used for rules which are not expressed as behavioural models, interactions or measures of ef

viewpoints.name: Lr - Lines of Development
viewpoints.notes: The Lr Viewpoint is primarily intended to support the acquisition process across multiple projects or programmes, highlighting dependencies the logical dependencies between capabilities, projects and

viewpoints.name: L2-L3 - Logical Concept
viewpoints.notes: The L2-L3 Viewpoint is concerned with providing an executive level, scenario-based communication of the architecture purpose, scope and content.

viewpoints.name: NAFv4-ADMBw Physical Resource Specification Viewpoints
viewpoints.notes: NAFv4-ADMBw Physical Resource Specification Viewpoints

viewpoints.name: P1 - Resource Types
viewpoints.notes: The P1 Viewpoint collects together all the Resource Types in the architecture together with a depiction of their performance characteristics. P1 also provides a summary of the technologies and compete

viewpoints.name: P2 - Resource Structure
viewpoints.notes: The P2 Viewpoint links together the operational and physical architecture viewpoints by depicting how types of Resource are structured and interact to realize the logical architecture specified in L2,

viewpoints.name: P3 - Resource Connectivity
viewpoints.notes: The networks and pathways documented in a P3 Viewpoint represent the physical implementation of the logical flows identified in a L2, Logical Scenario, or L3, Node Interactions View.

viewpoints.name: P4 - Resource Functions
viewpoints.notes: The Functionality Description provides detailed information regarding the allocation of functions to resources, and flows between Resource Functions. The P4 Viewpoint is the Physical Resource counterp

viewpoints.name: P5 - Resource States
viewpoints.notes: The P5 Viewpoint identifies the states a Resource can be, the allowable changes between those states, and the stimuli (e.g. triggers and events) that cause the state changes.

viewpoints.name: P6 - Resource Sequence
viewpoints.notes: The P6 Viewpoint is valuable for moving to the next level of detail from the initial solution design, to help define a sequence of functions and Resource Interactions, and to ensure that each particip

viewpoints.name: P7 -  Data Model
viewpoints.notes: The P7 Viewpoint is one of the architectural products closest to actual system design in the NAF. It is used to describe how the information represented in the L7 Logical Data Model Viewpoint is imple

viewpoints.name: P8 - Resource Constraints
viewpoints.notes: The P8 Viewpoint describes constraints on the Resources, Resource Functions, data and communications that make up a Physical Architecture.

viewpoints.name: Pr - Configuration Management
viewpoints.notes: The Pr Viewpoint provides an overview of how Resource Assets change over time (note that NAF v3.1 only allowed for Capability Configurations whereas now this is opened up to all Resource Types). It sh

viewpoints.name: L4-P4 - Activity To Function Mapping
viewpoints.notes: The L4-P4 Viewpoint depicts the mapping of Resource Functions (and optionally, the resources that provide them) to operational activities and/or service functions. For operational activities it thus i

viewpoints.name: NAFv4-ADMBw Service Specification Viewpoints
viewpoints.notes: NAFv4-ADMBw Service Specification Viewpoints

viewpoints.name: S1 - Service Taxonomy
viewpoints.notes: The purpose of the S1 Viewpoint is to provide a governance structure for a Service-Oriented Architecture. Along with S3, Service Interfaces, it specifies a standard library of service specifications f

viewpoints.name: S2 - Service Structure
viewpoints.notes: The S2 Viewpoint is concerned with identification and description of how services are structured to create a higher-aggregated service. To provide highlevel views, dependencies to other services, node

viewpoints.name: S3 - Service Interfaces
viewpoints.notes: The S3 Viewpoint is concerned with the identification and definition of service interfaces.

viewpoints.name: S4 - Service Functions
viewpoints.notes: The S4 Viewpoint is the key behavioural specification for services. Equivalent in nature to L4, Logical Activities and P4, Resources Functions, it specifies a set of functions that a service implement

viewpoints.name: S5 - Service States
viewpoints.notes: The S5 Viewpoint is a specification of the allowable states of a service, and the possible transitions between them. This specification constrains how implementations of the service will behave.  It i

viewpoints.name: S8 - Service Policy
viewpoints.notes: The S8 Viewpoint specifies constraints against services to which implementations must conform.

viewpoints.name: Sr - Service Roadmap
viewpoints.notes: The Sr Viewpoint supports the Service Audit process by providing a method to identify gaps or duplications in service provision. Sr indicates service lifetime evolutions, which are derived from delive

viewpoints.name: C1-S1 - Capability to Service Mapping
viewpoints.notes: A C1-S1 Viewpoint presents a simple mapping of services to capabilities, showing which services contribute to which capability.

viewpoints.name: NAFv4-ADMBw Requirement Viewpoints
viewpoints.notes: NAFv4-ADMBw Requirement Viewpoints
